title: How to find the complement of a set - Quora

response.answer_text: Union( A U B) , intersection( A n B) , complement(A') & difference(A -B) are all 4 fundamental Set Operations. Complement of any set is found as shown below… A = { 1,2,3,4,5,6,7,…….10} B= { 4,5,6 } Here, we notice that B is a subset of A & complement of set B , is the set of those elements , which are present in A but not in B. => B' = { 1,2,3,7,8,9,10} ie, cancell out common elements from both & whatever is left in A, is B'. There's a difference between Complement Operation & Difference Operation. That is …. While finding difference (A-B) , it's not necessary that one set should be the sub set of the other. Like A = {1,2,3,4,5,6,7} & B= { 3,5,8,9,10} . Here B is not a subset of A. So, the set {1,2,4,6,7} is not B' but it is A-B. while finding complement , as shown above , one set should be the sub set of the other. Or one set should be the Universal set.

First, find the global set which concerns your set. Then, remove elements of the set you have from this global set. This gives you the complement of the set you want to obtain. For ex : Let A={1,2,3,4} be set within all integers I. Here, I becomes my global set. A’( complement of A) will now be I - A, which is all integers except 1,2,3 and 4.

Let U={1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8} & A ={1,4,5,7} then A' = { 2,3,6,8} 【 U is the universal set , without this we cannot find complement set. A should be the subset of U, that is all the elements A should be in U. The elements which are not in A but in U is called complement of A , that is denoted by A'】

Let A be the set of which you want to find out the complement. When all sets under consideration are considered to be subsets of a given set U, The complement of set A is the set of elements which are not in A but in U. i.e, Complement (A)=U-A

In set theory, the complement of a set A refers to elements not in A. When all sets under consideration are considered to be subsets of a given set U, the absolute complementof A is the set of elements in U but not in A. Source : https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complement_(set_theory)&ved=2ahUKEwiE2NvLjYfjAhVUSX0KHSMmBmsQFjANegQIChAG&usg=AOvVaw3E5hCUyOFCxguuKif7zkoT :-)

By definition the complement of a set is any element not in the set. Example: Consider the set of whole numbers. It is made of a set of even whole numbers and a set of odd whole numbers. In this example the set of even whole numbers has a complement equivalent to the set of odd whole numbers.

If the set is (say) A , and the universal set is (say), U, then U - A gives the complement of the set A. If the universal set is not defined , then complement cannot be found out.

If A be any set, it's complement is defined by A'={x: x€U, x doesn't€A,U is universal set}. Suppose if we consider U={1,2,3,…} i.e. set of all natural number and A={1,2} then A'=U-A={3,4,….} i.e. set of all natural number start from 3.
